questions.text: A 30-year-old individual is scheduled to donate blood for a local blood drive. To ensure the safety of the blood supply, the donor's blood will be screened for various infectious diseases. Among the following options, which one is typically NOT included in the routine screening for donated blood?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dengue

Option D:

Dengue fever is a viral illness transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. Unlike some of the other diseases listed, routine screening for Dengue in donated blood is not typically performed. This is because Dengue is primarily transmitted by mosquitoes rather than through blood transfusions.

Explanation:

Option A. Malaria is routinely screened for in donated blood because it is caused by parasites transmitted through the bite of infected mosquitoes. Screening helps prevent the transmission of malaria through blood transfusions.

Option B.  Hepatitis B is a viral infection that can be transmitted through blood transfusions. Screening for Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is essential to prevent the transmission of the virus to recipients of donated blood.

Option C. Screening for HIV is crucial in donated blood to prevent the transmission of the virus to recipients. HIV screening typically involves testing for antibodies to HIV-1 and HIV-2, ensuring the safety of the blood supply.

Educational objective:

While diseases such as HIV, Hepatitis B, and Malaria are routinely screened for in donated blood to ensure the safety of the blood supply, Dengue is not typically included in routine screening protocols as it is primarily transmitted by mosquitoes rather than through blood transfusions.

questions.text: An elderly male with dragging sensation in abdomen presents in the OPD. His cell count had elevated total leucocyte count and increased platelet count. His peripheral smear shows metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophilia and basophilia (image given for reference). Which of the following is the likely genetic anomaly present in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. t (9; 22)

Option A:

The increased cell count (leucocytes and platelets) with peripheral smear showing metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophilia and basophilia (mixed myeloid lineage) is suggestive of a diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia. Two other features also fit in the diagnosis:

  • Age of the patient (peak incidence in 5/6th decade of life)
  • The dragging sensation (can be due to splenomegaly seen in CML patients)

Explanation:

Option B: t (15;17): is associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). It involves the fusion of the PML (promyelocytic leukemia) gene on chromosome 15 with the RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) gene on chromosome 17, resulting in the PML-RARA fusion gene. This fusion gene plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of APL.

Option C: t (8;14): is associated with Burkitt's lymphoma. It involves the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the immunoglobulin heavy chain gene on chromosome 14. The dysregulation of c-MYC, a proto-oncogene, contributes to the rapid and uncontrolled proliferation of B cells in Burkitt's lymphoma.

Option D: t (8;21): is associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), particularly the subtype known as AML with t(8;21), also called AML-M2. It involves the fusion of the AML1 (acute myeloid leukemia 1) gene on chromosome 21 with the ETO (eight-twenty-one) gene on chromosome 8, resulting in the AML1-ETO fusion gene.

Educational Objective:

The genetic anomaly likely present in an elderly male with an elevated leukocyte and platelet count, peripheral smear showing metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophilia, and basophilia is t (9;22), which is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/e p622)

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy with no significant past medical history is brought to the pediatrician by his parents who are concerned about his recent onset of spontaneous bruising and a single episode of nose bleeding that took longer than expected to cease. The child has no known allergies, and there is no family history of bleeding disorders. On physical examination, the paediatrician notes several bruises of varying sizes on his legs and arms, as well as petechiae on his ankles. Initial laboratory tests reveal an elevated prothrombin time (PT) and an elevated activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), but a normal platelet count and bleeding time (BT). What is the most likely defect in this child's coagulation pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Common pathway

 

Option D:

 

Defects in the common pathway affect factors that are involved in both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways (such as factors X, V, II [prothrombin], and I [fibrinogen]) and would lead to elevations in both PT and aPTT, as seen in this patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Extrinsic pathway: A defect in the extrinsic pathway would typically lead to an isolated elevation of PT, as this pathway is evaluated by the PT test. This does not explain the elevated aPTT observed in the patient.

 

Option B. Intrinsic pathway: A defect in the intrinsic pathway would typically result in an isolated elevation of aPTT, as this pathway is evaluated by the aPTT test. This also does not explain the elevated PT observed in the patient.

 

Option C. Platelet function: Platelet function defects usually result in a prolonged bleeding time (BT) and normal coagulation tests (PT and aPTT). Since the patient has a normal BT, this is unlikely to be the correct diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Defect in the extrinsic pathway causes elevation of PT
  • Defect in the intrinsic pathway causes elevation of aPTT.
  • Defect in common pathway cause elevation of both PT and aPTT.
  • Platelet function defect causes elevation of BT.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 120

questions.text: Most common blood transfusion reaction is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

Option A:

FNHTR is the most common type of transfusion reaction. It is characterized by fever, chills, and rigors without evidence of hemolysis. It is usually caused by a reaction between the recipient's immune system and leukocytes in the transfused blood.

Explanation:

Option B. Hemolysis: it is a serious but less common transfusion reaction. It occurs when red blood cells are destroyed, leading to the release of hemoglobin into the bloodstream. Hemolysis can be caused by various factors, including ABO incompatibility, improper storage, or bacterial contamination.

Option C. Transmission of Infections: While the transmission of infections is a serious concern in blood transfusions, it is not the most common transfusion reaction. Stringent screening and testing procedures for donated blood have significantly reduced the risk of transmitting infections, making FNHTR more common.

Option D. Electrolyte Imbalance: Electrolyte imbalances are not a common transfusion reaction. However, in some cases, transfusions with large volumes of blood or specific blood components can lead to electrolyte disturbances. This is not the primary or most common transfusion reaction.

Educational objective:

 Most common blood transfusion reaction is Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 667

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a chronic history of heartburn and regurgitation undergoes an upper endoscopy. Biopsy of the distal esophagus shows the presence of columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Which of the following is true of Barrett esophagus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a known precursor of adenocarcinoma of the esophagus

 

Option D:

 

Barrett esophagus is a complication of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease and is a precursor to esophageal adenocarcinoma.

 

Barrett esophagus intestinal is columnar metaplasia of the esopha¬geal squamous epithelium (squamous–to-columnar). The columnar epithelium is often of the intestinal type with goblet cells. Barrett esophagus is a complication of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease and is a precursor of esophageal adenocarcinoma. The most common location is in the distal (lower) third of the esophagus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. The biopsy shows squamous to columnar metaplasia, not the other way around.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Barrett esophagus is a known precursor of esophageal adenocarcinoma, not gastric carcinoma.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Barrett esophagus most commonly occurs in the distal (lower) third of the esophagus, not the proximal (upper) third.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett esophagus shows intestinal columnar metaplasia of the esophageal squamous epithelium. It is a precursor lesion to esophageal adenocarcinoma, commonly located in the distal third of the esophagus.

 

Important risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma include Barrett’s esophagus, GERD, obesity, Tobacco use and radiation exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 762

questions.text: Origin of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/SLL is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Naïve B cells

 

Option C:

 

Explanation:

 

Ig genes of some CLL/SLL are somatically hypermutated, whereas others are not, suggesting that the cell of origin may be either a post-germinal center memory B cell or a naive B cell. It is not originating from progenitor B cell or mature B cell.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cell of origin for CLL/SLL is the naive B cell, which may or may not undergo somatic hypermutation, suggesting that CLL/SLL can arise from a pre-germinal center B cell.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with fatigue, weakness, and recurrent infections. Flow cytometry analysis of bone marrow aspirate shows infiltration of small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and lymphoplasmacytoid cells. The patient is diagnosed with lymphoplasmacytoid lymphoma. Which immunoglobulin is most likely to be associated with this lymphoma subtype?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgM

Option D:

  • Lymphoplasmacytoid lymphoma (or Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia) is a B cell neoplasm presenting in 6th or 7th decade of life having features similar to CLL/ SLL and multiple myeloma (MM). Like MM, there is presence of a ‘M’ or monoclonal spike (caused due to IgM)
  • In multiple myeloma, the M spike is seen due to IgG.

Explanation:

Option A: (IgG): While IgG is the most common immunoglobulin produced in multiple myeloma, it is not typically associated with lymphoplasmacytoid lymphoma, also known as Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia.

Option B: (IgA): IgA is another immunoglobulin that can be produced in multiple myeloma but is less commonly associated with lymphoplasmacytoid lymphoma.

Option C: (IgD): IgD paraproteinemia is very rare in plasma cell dyscrasias and is not commonly seen in lymphoplasmacytoid lymphoma.

Educational Objective:

Lymphoplasmacytoid lymphoma, known as Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia, is most commonly associated with the overproduction of monoclonal IgM.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 604)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male involved in a motor vehicle collision requires a massive transfusion due to severe hemorrhagic shock. He receives 15 units of packed red blood cells within a 24-hour period. Which of the following complications is likely to result after several units of blood have been transferred?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic alkalosis

Option A:

Metabolic alkalosis is a common complication after a massive transfusion due to the metabolism of citrate, which is used as an anticoagulant in stored blood, into bicarbonate. Lactate, which may accumulate in stored blood due to hypoperfusion and anaerobic metabolism, is also converted to bicarbonate when normal perfusion is restored.

Explanation:

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: While metabolic acidosis can be present initially due to hypoperfusion and lactic acidosis, the administration of several units of blood typically results in the correction of the acidosis, potentially overshooting into alkalosis due to the reasons mentioned above.

Option C. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis typically results from hyperventilation, which may occur in patients in pain or with anxiety, but it is not directly related to the transfusion of blood products.

Option D. Respiratory acidosis: Respiratory acidosis is caused by hypoventilation and the accumulation of carbon dioxide in the blood. It is not a common complication associated with blood transfusion itself, unless there are underlying respiratory issues or transfusion-related complications affecting lung function.

Educational Objective:

Massive Transfusion is defined as the need to transfuse from one to two times the patient’s normal blood vol­ume. In a normal adult, this is equivalent to 10-20 units. Most common abnormality is metabolic alkalosis. It re­sults from conversion of citrate (present in stored blood) and lactate (accumulated due to hypoperfusion) to bicar­bonate.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 668

choices.text: Increase in thickness of the mucosa
Increase in inflammatory cells in lamina propria

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and has recently developed a pruritic vesicular rash. Serology tests are positive for anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. A biopsy of the small intestine is performed. Which histological finding is least likely to be associated with her probable condition, celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased in thickness of the mucosa

 

Option B:

 

While there is crypt hyperplasia and increased cell turnover, the mucosal thickness does not increase in celiac disease; instead, there is villous atrophy which makes the mucosa appear flat.

 

Characteristic histological features seen on duode­nal/ jejunal biopsy in celiac sprue are:

 

  • Absence or reduced height of villi, resulting in ‘flat’ appearance.

  • Crypt cell hyperplasia compensate for villous atrophy and mucosal thickness remain same

  • Increased lymphocytes and plasma cells in lamina propria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Crypt hyperplasia is seen in celiac disease and reflects an effort of the mucosa to regenerate despite ongoing damage.

 

Option C. Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes are a diagnostic feature of celiac disease, often exceeding 25 lymphocytes per 100 enterocytes.

 

Option D. In celiac disease, the lamina propria typically shows increased numbers of inflammatory cells, including lymphocytes and plasma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In celiac disease, despite crypt hyperplasia compensating for villous atrophy, the overall thickness of the mucosa does not increase, maintaining a 'flat' appearance.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 785

choices.text: FISH in the peripheral blood smear

questions.text: A male patient with splenomegaly with myeloid hyperplasia. What’s is the next best investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. FISH in the peripheral blood smear

Option D:

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that can be applied to detect specific genetic abnormalities and is invaluable for diagnosis of CML (more likely from the history given in the question).

Explanation:

Option A: Whole-body PET CT (Positron Emission Tomography with Computed Tomography) is a valuable imaging tool, particularly in the evaluation of lymphomas and solid tumors. However, it may not be the first-line investigation for myeloid hyperplasia or diseases primarily involving the bone marrow.

Option B: Leucocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) is an enzyme that can be measured to assess the activity of neutrophils. Low LAP scores may be associated with conditions like chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). However, this test alone might not provide a definitive diagnosis and is often used in conjunction with other tests.

Option C: Immunophenotyping is a crucial investigation in the context of hematological disorders. It involves the analysis of cell surface markers on blood or bone marrow cells but is more useful for other leukemias like ALL, AML or CLL.

Educational Objective:

For a male patient with splenomegaly and myeloid hyperplasia, the next best investigation is Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) in the peripheral blood smear, particularly to detect chromosomal abnormalities such as the Philadelphia chromosome in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/e p482)

choices.text: It involves both alleles of RB at chromosome locus 13q14
In sporadic cases, both normal RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast
Familial type is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait
In familial cases, children inherit one defective copy of the RB gene and the other copy is normal

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Knudson's two-hit hypothesis theory on retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Familial type is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait

 

Option C:

 

Retinoblastoma is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.

Knudson's hypothesis, also known as the two-hit hypothesis or multiple-hit hypothesis states that cancer is the result of accumulated mutations in a cell's DNA.
Explanation:

Option A. Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of RB at chromosome locus 13q14, are required to produce retinoblastoma.

Option B. In sporadic cases, both normal RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits).

Option D. In familial cases, children inherit one defective copy of the RB gene in the germline (the first hit), and the other copy is normal. Retinoblastoma develops when the normal RB allele is mutated in retinoblasts as a result of a spontaneous somatic mutation (the second hit).

Educational Objective:

Familial retinoblastoma is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, not autosomal recessive. According to Knudson's two-hit hypothesis, a single inherited mutation in one allele of the RB gene is sufficient to predispose to retinoblastoma, but a second somatic mutation in the other allele must occur for the cancer to develop.

questions.text: As a primary healthcare worker, you collect blood samples to measure fasting blood glucose levels in a population screening for diabetes. To ensure accurate results, which anticoagulant should be used to prevent glycolysis in the sample during transport to the laboratory?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Potassium oxalate + sodium fluoride

Option C:

Potassium oxalate + sodium fluoride: Sodium fluoride inhibits glycolysis by inhibiting the enolase enzyme in the glycolytic pathway, ensuring glucose levels remain stable after blood collection. Potassium oxalate acts as an anticoagulant. This combination is ideal for glucose estimation in blood samples.

Explanation:

Option A. EDTA: Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) is commonly used as an anticoagulant in hematology for complete blood count testing but not for glucose estimation because it does not prevent glycolysis.

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that prevents blood clotting by inhibiting thrombin but does not prevent glycolysis, so it is not the best choice for glucose testing.

Option D. Tri Sodium citrate: Trisodium citrate is used mainly for coagulation tests and does not inhibit glycolysis, making it unsuitable for glucose estimation.

Educational objective:

Direct quote ‘enolase enzyme in the glycolysis is inhibited by fluoride, and when blood samples are taken for measurement of glucose, it is collected in tubes containing fluoride to inhibit glycolysis.’

 

Ref: Henry’s 21st /188, Harper 27th/152

choices.text: Elevated total leukocyte count
Leucocyte alkaline phosphatase
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate

questions.text: The difference between leukemia and leukemoid reaction is done by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Leucocyte alkaline phosphatase

Option B:

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) is a marker that can help distinguish between chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and a leukemoid reaction. In CML, LAP is typically low, while in a leukemoid reaction, it is normal or elevated.

Explanation:

Option A. Elevated total leukocyte count: Both leukemia and leukemoid reaction can result in an elevated total leukocyte count. However, the specific characteristics of the white blood cells, along with other parameters, help differentiate between the two.

Option C. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR): is a non-specific marker of inflammation and is not commonly used to differentiate between leukemia and leukemoid reaction.

Option D. Presence of immature cells: The presence of immature or blast cells is not helpful for differentiating between leukemia from a leukemoid reaction. The percentage of immature cells is a crucial factor in distinguishing leukemia from a leukemoid reaction.

Educational objective:

Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score helps differentiate between chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), where it is typically low, and a leukemoid reaction, where it is normal or elevated.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 584)

questions.text: The following have strong causal association with H. pylori infection except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duodenal adenomas

 

Option D:

 

  • H. pylori infection is not strongly associated with duodenal adenomas, which are benign tumors of the duodenal epithelium.
  • Duodenal adenomas are more commonly associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or sporadic mutations rather than H. pylori infection. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic gastritis: There is a strong causal association between H. pylori infection and chronic gastritis. H. pylori is a major cause of chronic active gastritis, characterized by inflammation of the gastric mucosa.

 

Option B. Peptic ulcer disease: H. pylori infection is strongly associated with the development of peptic ulcer disease, particularly duodenal ulcers. H. pylori colonization in the gastric mucosa can lead to mucosal damage and ulcer formation.

 

Option C. Gastric carcinoma: H. pylori infection is considered a major risk factor for the development of gastric carcinoma, particularly intestinal-type gastric adenocarcinoma. Chronic inflammation and mucosal damage induced by H. pylori contribute to the carcinogenic process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Various gastrointestinal conditions strong causal association with H. pylori infection, including chronic gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, and gastric carcinoma, but Duodenal adenomas do not have a strong causal association with H. pylori infection.

 

Summary:

 

  • H. pylori → chronic gastritis → hyperplastic gastric polyps 
  • H. pylori → gastric adenomas/adenocarcinoma (via atrophic gastritis & intestinal metaplasia) 
  • H. pylori → duodenal ulcers 
  • H. pylori → duodenal adenomas (Not causally related)

 

H. pylori-Associated Infections and Tumors

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 774

choices.text: Mallory-Weiss tears
Zenker’s diverticulum
Schatzki rings

questions.text: A patient complains of pain in the upper portion of his neck on swallowing. He occasionally regurgitates undigested food shortly after eating. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of his problems?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker’s diverticulum

Option B:

  • Zenker's diverticulum: This is a pharyngoesophageal outpouching that occurs above the upper esophageal sphincter at a weak point in the pharyngeal musculature (Killian's triangle). It's called a "false" diverticulum because only the mucosal layer herniates through the muscle layer. Symptoms can include dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, aspiration, and halitosis.
  • This is the classic presentation of Zenker’s diverticulum, which is a false diverticulum formed by herniation of the mucosa at a point of weakness at the junction of the pharynx and esophagus in the posterior hypopharyn¬geal wall. It is also associated with halitosis, and if the diverticulum fills completely with food, it can cause dys¬phagia or obstruction of the esophagus.

Explanation:

Option A. Mallory-Weiss tears: These are longitudinal mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction or gastric cardia. They often occur after forceful or prolonged vomiting and can lead to hematemesis. Alcoholics or individuals with bulimia are at a higher risk for this condition due to repeated episodes of vomiting.

Option C. Schatzki rings: These are thin, circumferential, mucosal rings that occur at the squamocolumnar junction in the distal esophagus. They can cause intermittent dysphagia for solid foods and are often associated with a sliding hiatal hernia.

Option D. Traction diverticula: These are "true" diverticula involving all layers of the esophageal wall. They are typically located in the mid-esophagus and can be caused by pulling forces from outside the esophagus, such as from fibrosis in mediastinal lymph nodes.

Educational objective:

Zenker’s diverticulum is a false diverticulum formed by herniation of the mucosa at a point of weakness at the junction of the pharynx and esophagus in the posterior hypopharyn­geal wall.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /757

questions.text: The anticoagulant of choice for anticoagulation testing:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3.2% trisodium citrate

Option D:

Trisodium citrate is a calcium chelator and is commonly used as the anticoagulant of choice for coagulation testing particularly for tests like prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)

Explanation:

Option A. Heparin is an anticoagulant that acts by potentiating the activity of antithrombin III, thereby inhibiting thrombin and other coagulation factors. While heparin is commonly used in clinical settings for anticoagulation, it is not the anticoagulant of choice for anticoagulation testing, as it can interfere with clotting assays.

Option B. EDTA is an anticoagulant that chelates calcium ions, preventing the coagulation process by inhibiting clotting factors that depend on calcium. EDTA is commonly used for collecting blood samples for hematology studies, such as complete blood counts.

Option C. Sodium oxalate also chelates calcium ions, similar to EDTA, and is used for collecting blood samples for glucose testing (enolase acting as a glycolysis inhibitor).

Educational objective:

The anticoagulant of choice for anticoagulation testing is 3.2% trisodium citrate.

choices.text: Lymphocyte depleted Hodgkin’s disease
Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin’s disease

questions.text: The lymphocytic and histiocytic variant of Reed- Sternberg cell is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s disease

Option D:

Reed-Sternberg cells are large, abnormal cells that are characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s disease: In lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's disease, the Reed-Sternberg cells have a popcorn-like appearance and are surrounded by a nodular and infiltrate of lymphocytes.

Explanation:

Option A: Follicular center lymphoma: Reed-Sternberg cells are not typically associated with follicular center lymphoma, which is a subtype of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option B: In the lymphocyte-depleted subtype of Hodgkin's disease, the Reed-Sternberg cells are surrounded by a small number of lymphocytes and a significant number of histiocytes (macrophages). This variant is associated with a poorer prognosis compared to other subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option C: Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin’s disease: The nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin's disease typically features Reed-Sternberg cells with a lacunar (empty) appearance, surrounded by fibrous bands.

Educational Objective:

The lymphocytic and histiocytic (L&H) variant of Reed-Sternberg cells, often called "popcorn cells," is characteristic of lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s disease.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /613

choices.text: Infiltration of histiocytes in the lamina propria
Macrophages with PAS (+) material inside the lamina propria

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with arthralgia, chronic diarrhea, and weight loss. An upper GI endoscopy is performed, and duodenal biopsy samples are obtained. Histological examination of the biopsy will most likely reveal which of the following features consistent with Whipple's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Macrophages with PAS (+) material inside the lamina propria

 

Option C:

 

  • The presence of PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria containing small bacilli is a hallmark of Whipple's disease and helps differentiate it from other gastrointestinal diseases.

  • Hallmark of Whipple’s disease had been presence of PAS positive macrophages containing the characteristic small bacilli.  Also know that the presence of T. Whipplei outside of macrophages is more important indicator of active disease than is their presence inside the macrophages.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Histiocyte infiltration is a feature seen in many types of chronic inflammation of the GI tract and is not specific to Whipple's disease.

 

Option B. Granulomas are a histological finding seen in diseases like tuberculosis, sarcoidosis and Crohn's disease, but not typically in Whipple's disease.

 

Option D. Eosinophilic infiltration is more commonly seen in conditions associated with allergy, parasitic infection, or certain gastrointestinal disorders but not typically in Whipple's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histological hallmark of Whipple's disease is the presence of PAS-positive macrophages within the lamina propria, which contain the causative organism Tropheryma whipplei.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 796

choices.text: RBC corresponding to his red cell group and colloids/ crystalloid
Whole blood corresponding to his plasma group
O positive RBC and colloids/crystalloid

questions.text: A 55 years old male accident victim in casualty urgently needs blood. The blood bank is unable to determine his ABO group, as his red cell group and plasma group do not match. Emergency transfusion of the patient should be with:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) O positive RBC and colloids/crystalloid

Option C:

Selection of blood for emergency transfusion

  • If patient’s blood group is known, unmatched blood group of the same group may be used.
  • If the patient’s blood cannot be determined, Group O red blood cells should be chosen. The use of such unmatched blood should be Rh (–ve) when used in woman of child-bearing age in whom we do not want sensitization to Rh antigen. As Rh-negative blood is often in limited supply, Rh positive blood is used in the emergency transfusion of older females and males of unknown blood group. In such cases sensitization may occur but the risk of an immediate hemolytic reaction is low. O blood group is the universal donor and therefore, should be given to this patient.
    • positive RBCs and colloids/crystalloid: In emergencies where the blood type is unknown or cannot be confirmed, it is standard to use O positive RBCs for males and older females because of the availability and lower risk of causing an immediate hemolytic reaction. Colloids or crystalloids can be used to maintain volume.

Explanation:

Option A. RBCs corresponding to his red cell group and colloids/crystalloid: While it might seem intuitive to use RBCs corresponding to his red cell group, in cases where there is a discrepancy and the patient's blood group cannot be confirmed, it is safer to use group O RBCs, which are considered universal donors.

Option B. Whole blood corresponding to his plasma group: When the ABO group cannot be determined, using whole blood of a specific group is not recommended due to the risk of an ABO incompatibility reaction.

Option D. AB negative whole blood: AB negative blood is considered the universal plasma donor, not the universal RBC donor. This option could result in an ABO incompatibility reaction if the patient is not AB negative.

Educational Objective:

O positive RBCs can be used in males and non-childbearing potential females, with colloids or crystalloid solutions to manage volume, as this approach minimizes the risk of hemolytic transfusion reactions.

 

Ref: Wintrobes 12th 836

choices.text: Platelet precursors in the bone marrow are normal or elevated

questions.text: In myelodysplastic syndrome, the following statement is incorrect:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Always has hypocellular bone marrow

 

Option C:

 

Always has hypocellular bone marrow: This statement is incorrect. MDS is often associated with a hypercellular or normocellular bone marrow and rarely hypocellular bone marrow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Platelet precursors in the bone marrow are often normal or elevated in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). This condition is characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis, and it commonly leads to cytopenias in the peripheral blood.  Thrombocytopenia is a common feature in MDS, and it contributes to the increased risk of bleeding in affected individuals.

 

Option B: Leucocyte precursors in the bone marrow are normal or elevated: This statement is correct

 

Option D: Refractory anemia: This statement is correct. Refractory anemia is a common subtype of MDS, characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis leading to anemia that does not respond well to conventional treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bone marrow in MDS is hypercellular (most commonly) or normocellular (sometimes) or rarely hypocellular

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 620-1)

questions.text: A 46-year-old female presents with dysphagia, especially with solid foods, and has noted a burning sensation in her tongue. She reports a history of fatigue and breathlessness on exertion. On examination, her tongue is smooth and atrophic, and laboratory tests reveal a microcytic anemia. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Megaloblastic anemia

Option C:

Megaloblastic anemia: Incorrectly associated. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is associated with iron-deficiency anemia, not megaloblastic anemia (which is typically due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency).

Explanation:

Option A. Glossitis: Correctly associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome, representing the smooth, atrophic tongue observed in this patient.

Option B. Esophageal webs: Also correctly associated, potentially explaining the patient's dysphagia for solids.

Option D. Esophageal dysphagia: Correctly associated, as this symptom is often due to esophageal webs or strictures present in Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Educational Objective:

The clinical features of Plummer-Vinson syndrome, include glossitis, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs, and differentiate it from megaloblastic anemia.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome, also known as Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome, is characterized by the triad of glossitis, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. So, the correct answer is (c) Megaloblastic anemia.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/757

questions.text: A female with chronic dysphagia undergoes an upper endoscopy that reveals massive dilation of the distal esophagus. The esophagus is kinked and tortuous and partly filled with undigested foods. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia

 

Option A:

 

Achalasia: Correct. Achalasia is defined by impaired esophageal motility and relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter, causing food accumulation and dilation of the esophagus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Barrett’s Esophagus: Incorrect for this scenario. Barrett’s esophagus involves the replacement of the lower esophageal squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium and is associated with chronic GERD, not presenting with significant dilation and kinking as described.

 

Option C. Hiatal Hernia: Incorrect. A hiatal hernia occurs when a portion of the stomach protrudes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity. While it can cause reflux and some degree of dysphagia, it typically doesn't result in the massive dilation and tortuosity of the esophagus.

 

Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: Incorrect. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is associated with iron-deficiency anemia, glossitis, and esophageal webs. It does not present with the dilation and tortuosity as described in the vignette.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characteristic presentation of achalasia includes chronic dysphagia, dilation, and tortuosity of the esophagus, often with retained food material, which is distinguishable from other conditions such as Barrett's esophagus, hiatal hernia, and Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

 

Symptoms: Progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids, regurgitation of undigested food, weight loss, sometimes chest pain.

 

Imaging (Barium swallow): “Bird-beak” appearance

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 757

choices.text: Decreased growth of luminal bacteria
Decreased likelihood of developing gastric carcino­ma
Decreased plasma concentration of gastrin
Increased production of macrocytic red blood cells

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a several-month history of epigastric pain, which is relieved by eating. She has a past medical history significant for Hashimoto's thyroiditis. On physical examination, she is found to have mild pallor. Laboratory tests reveal a serum vitamin B12 level of 150 pg/mL (normal: 200-900 pg/mL) and a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 110 fL (normal: 80-100 fL). An upper endoscopy shows atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions would mostly likely be associated with chronic gastritis (Type A) resulting from autoimmune destruction of parietal cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased production of macrocytic red blood cells

 

Option D:

 

Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells impairs the production of intrinsic factor, which is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. Vitamin B12 deficiency can result in megaloblastic anemia, characterized by the production of macrocytic (large) red blood cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chronic atrophic gastritis, especially when caused by an autoimmune process that destroys parietal cells, leads to hypochlorhydria or achlorhydria. This can result in an increased growth of luminal bacteria, as the acidic environment of the stomach normally serves to limit bacterial overgrowth.

 

Option B: The risk of gastric carcinoma is actually increased in the setting of chronic gastritis, particularly when atrophy is involved. The ongoing inflammation and cellular regeneration can predispose to malignant transformation.

 

Option C: In autoimmune gastritis, the destruction of parietal cells typically leads to a decreased secretion of hydrochloric acid. This would usually result in a compensatory increase in plasma gastrin levels due to loss of negative feedback.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In chronic gastritis type A (autoimmune gastritis), the destruction of parietal cells results in impaired production of intrinsic factor and subsequent vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to megaloblastic anemia with macrocytic red blood cells.

 

 Ref: Robbins 10th/ 769

questions.text: Which one of the following Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas is aggressive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Burkitt Lymphoma

Option B:

Burkitt Lymphoma is considered an aggressive Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma. It is characterized by a high proliferation rate of rapidly dividing cells and is often associated with the translocation involving the MYC gene. Burkitt Lymphoma can occur in three main forms: endemic, sporadic, and immunodeficiency-associated subtypes.

Explanation:

Option A: Follicular Lymphoma is an indolent (slow-growing) Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma. It has a more chronic course and tends to be less aggressive compared to Burkitt Lymphoma.

Option C: Small lymphocytic lymphoma is a low-grade, indolent lymphoma that is related to chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). It is characterized by the proliferation of small mature B-cells.

Option D: Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is typically an indolent lymphoma characterized by the infiltration of the bone marrow and other tissues by small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and lymphoplasmacytic cells.

Educational Objective:

Burkitt Lymphoma is an aggressive Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma characterized by a high proliferation rate and MYC gene translocation. “Burkitt lymphoma is believed to be the fastest growing hu­man tumor”…direct line

 

(Ref: Robbin 10th 598)

questions.text: The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome is associated with a worse prognosis in patients with which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

Option A:

(Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia, ALL): In ALL, the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which involves the translocation t(9;22) resulting in the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, is associated with a more aggressive disease course and a poorer prognosis. This is because the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein has increased tyrosine kinase activity, which drives the leukemogenesis. Patients with Philadelphia chromosome-positive ALL often require more intensive treatment, such as tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) in addition to chemotherapy, and may be considered for stem cell transplantation.

Explanation:

Option B: (Acute Myelogenous Leukemia, AML): The Philadelphia chromosome is not commonly associated with AML. AML has other chromosomal abnormalities that are more predictive of prognosis, such as the presence of mutations in genes like FLT3, NPM1, or alterations like t(15;17) in acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).

Option C: (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, CLL): CLL is typically not associated with the Philadelphia chromosome. CLL has its own prognostic markers, such as deletions in chromosome 13q, 11q, and trisomy 12, or the mutation status of IGHV (immunoglobulin heavy chain variable region genes).

Option D: (Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia, CML): The Philadelphia chromosome is the hallmark of CML and is present in the vast majority of cases. The presence of this chromosome is part of the diagnostic criteria for CML and is not considered a worse prognostic factor within this disease context. The treatment for CML includes TKIs, which target the BCR-ABL1 protein resulting from the Philadelphia chromosome translocation.

Educational objective:

The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, a translocation from the long arm of chromosome 22 to chromosome 9 [t(9;22)], is associated with a favorable prognosis in chronic myelogenous leukemia but it associated with an unfavorable outcome in Acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 601)

questions.text: Burkitt’s lymphoma is associated most commonly with of the following translocations?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. t (8:14)

Option A:

Burkitt's lymphoma is most commonly associated with the translocation t(8:14). This translocation involves the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) gene on chromosome 14. The result of this translocation is the dysregulation and constitutive activation of the c-MYC oncogene, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation characteristic of Burkitt's lymphoma.

Explanation:

Option B: t (9:22): is associated with Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML) and Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) but not Burkitt's lymphoma.

Option C: t (11;14): is associated with Mantle Cell Lymphoma but not Burkitt's lymphoma.

Option D: t (8:21): is associated with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) with maturation but not Burkitt's lymphoma.

Educational Objective:

Burkitt's lymphoma is most commonly associated with the translocation t(8;14), involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the immunoglobulin heavy chain gene on chromosome 14.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 602)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with dyspepsia and an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a lesion in the stomach. Histopathological examination is consistent with gastric carcinoma. Which type of gastric carcinoma is associated with the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superficial spreading

 

Option D:

 

Superficial spreading gastric carcinoma, confined to the mucosal layer, is likely to have a more favorable prognosis because of the potential for complete surgical removal and lower likelihood of metastasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Linitis plastica is known for its poor prognosis because the diffuse infiltration makes it difficult to completely resect and treat effectively.

 

Option B: Polypoidal growths tend to be localized and can often be respected, leading to a relatively better prognosis compared to more invasive forms.

 

Option C: Ulcerative gastric cancers can vary in prognosis. If the ulceration is superficial with minimal invasion, the prognosis can be good, but deeply invasive ulcerations are associated with a poorer outcome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superficial spreading gastric carcinoma, which is confined to the mucosal layer and does not invade deeper gastric wall layers, is associated with the best prognosis among the types of gastric carcinoma listed.

 

Why Superficial Spreading Has the Best Prognosis:

 

  • Limited to the mucosa or submucosa (early gastric cancer).
  • Even with wide lateral spread, the depth of invasion is minimal.
  • Often detected early with endoscopic screening (especially in Japan).
  • Excellent 5-year survival rates (>90%) after surgical resection.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 775

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with a family history of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN I) presents with symptoms of peptic ulcer disease that have not responded to standard treatment. Laboratory tests show elevated serum gastrin levels. Which of the following is the most common functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor associated with MEN I in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastrinoma

 

Option A:

 

Gastrinomas are often the most common functional neuroendocrine tumor in patients with MEN I and are directly related to the symptoms described.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN I) is characterized by tumors involving the parathyroid glands, pancreas, and pituitary gland. Gastrinomas, which are tumors of the pancreas or duodenum that secrete gastrin, are a common functional tumor associated with MEN I. These tumors can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by gastric acid hypersecretion and peptic ulcers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Although insulinomas are seen in MEN I, they are not as common as gastrinomas and typically present with symptoms related to hypoglycemia, not peptic ulcer disease.

 

Option C. Lipomas are benign and not typically functional, meaning they do not secrete hormones that lead to the clinical syndromes associated with MEN I.

 

Option D. Glucagonomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors and when present, are associated with a distinct set of clinical features that are not described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors associated with MEN I and often present with peptic ulcer disease due to gastric acid hypersecretion.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /773

questions.text: Irradiation of blood prior to transfusion prevents which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Graft versus host disease

 

Option C:

 

(Graft versus Host Disease - GVHD): GVHD occurs when donor T cells attack the recipient's body. Irradiation of blood products deactivates these T cells, thereby preventing GVHD, which is especially important in immunocompromised recipients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: (TRALI - Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury): TRALI is a serious complication characterized by acute respiratory distress following transfusion. It is thought to be caused by donor antibodies against recipient leukocytes. Irradiation does not prevent TRALI.

 

Option B: (HLA alloimmunization): HLA alloimmunization can occur when a patient develops antibodies against HLA antigens from transfused blood. While leukoreduction can reduce the risk, irradiation of blood products does not prevent HLA alloimmunization.

 

Option D: (Immunomodulation): Immunomodulation refers to the potential immune system changes in transfusion recipients, potentially leading to an increased risk of postoperative infections and malignancy recurrence. Irradiation’s role in preventing immunomodulation is not clearly established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irradiation of white and red blood cells prior to transfusion is primarily used to prevent graft versus host disease.

 

What happens in Transfusion associated-GVHD?

 

  • Donor T cells attack recipient tissues.
  • Occurs particularly in immunocompromised patients (e.g., post-transplant, chemotherapy).
  • It is often fatal.
  • Irradiation (typically with 25–30 Gy gamma rays) prevents T-cell proliferation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/e p671-2)

choices.text: It is involved in DNA repair
It is a tumor suppressor gene
It is not involved in colon cancer

questions.text: A patient presents with a family history of colon cancer. They undergo genetic testing, which reveals a mutation in the APC gene. Which of the following is true about APC?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a tumor suppressor gene

Option C:

It is a tumor suppressor gene. The APC gene encodes a protein that helps regulate cell division and may prevent cells from growing and dividing too rapidly or in an uncontrolled way. Mutations in the APC gene can lead to unchecked cellular proliferation, predisposing individuals to cancer, particularly colorectal cancer.

Explanation:

Option A.  It is a proto-oncogene. Proto-oncogenes are normal genes that can become oncogenes due to mutations or increased expression. Oncogenes can cause the cells to grow and proliferate excessively. The APC gene, however, functions as a tumor suppressor gene, not a proto-oncogene.

Option B. It is involved in DNA repair.  While DNA repair mechanisms are essential in the prevention of cancer, the APC gene itself is not primarily involved in DNA repair processes. Its primary function relates to the regulation of cell growth and division.

Option D. It is not involved in colon cancer. This statement is incorrect. The APC gene is implicated in colon cancer, as mutations in this gene are commonly found in both sporadic and hereditary forms of colorectal cancer.

Educational Objective:

APC gene is a tumor suppressor gene. Mutations in the APC gene lead to a loss of function, resulting in increased cell proliferation and a higher risk for developing colorectal cancer.

choices.text: WASP gene study

questions.text: A young boy presented with recurrent episodes of melena. The physician also found presence of dermatitis like rashes and multiple petechiae. His platelet count was low but red cell and white blood cell counts were normal. Which of the following is the diagnostic investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) WASP gene study

Option C:

WASP gene study refers to the genetic analysis of the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) gene. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, recurrent infections, and eczema. Given the clinical presentation described in the question, which includes low platelet count, dermatitis-like rashes, and petechiae, along with a young male patient, the possibility of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is high. Therefore, genetic analysis of the WASP gene is the appropriate diagnostic investigation in this case.

 

 

Explanation:

Option A. Anti-platelet antibodies are antibodies produced by the immune system against platelets, which can result in conditions like immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). While it could be considered in cases of thrombocytopenia, the clinical presentation described in the question is more indicative of a specific underlying genetic disorder rather than an autoimmune cause.

Option B. Bone marrow examination is a valuable diagnostic tool in cases of unexplained thrombocytopenia to assess for abnormalities in platelet production or destruction. However, in this case, the clinical presentation and history strongly suggest a specific genetic disorder rather than a primary bone marrow disorder.

Option D. Platelet function analyzers are used to assess platelet function in various bleeding disorders. While they may be useful in certain contexts, the clinical presentation described in the question suggests a genetic disorder rather than a primary platelet dysfunction.

Educational objective:

The clinical presentation described, including thrombocytopenia, recurrent infections, and eczema, is suggestive of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, a rare X-linked recessive disorder. Genetic analysis of the WASP gene is the diagnostic investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis.

choices.text: May have a malignant neoplastic transformation
Ileum is the most common site

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with an asymptomatic mass in the upper abdomen found incidentally during a routine health check-up. An endoscopic ultrasound followed by a biopsy confirms the presence of a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Which of the following statements regarding GISTs is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ileum is the most common site

 

Option B:

 

The most common site for GISTs is the stomach, not the ileum. This statement is false and contrary to the typical presentation of GISTs.

 

Stomach is the most common site.  These have a tendency for malignant transformation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: GISTs have the potential for malignant transformation, which is consistent with their classification as a neoplastic disorder, potentially leading to cancer.

 

Option C: Mutations in the c-KIT gene are commonly associated with GISTs. These mutations are often pathognomonic and a therapeutic target for treatment.

 

Option D: Histologically, GISTs can display spindle-shaped cells, but they can also present with other patterns, such as epithelioid or mixed cell types.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for GISTs is the stomach.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 779

questions.text: All are true about thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grossly abnormal coagulation tests

 

Option D:

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a rare blood disorder characterized by the formation of microclots in small blood vessels throughout the body, leading to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. TTP is associated with a deficiency of ADAMTS13 (a disintegrin and metalloproteinase), an enzyme responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor. TTP doesn't grossly affect the standard coagulation tests. So, the coagulation tests such as PT (prothrombin time) and APTT (activated partial thromboplastin time) are typically normal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia: True. TTP is associated with the formation of microclots that damage red blood cells, leading to hemolysis.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: True. TTP is characterized by low platelet counts due to the formation of platelet-rich microclots.

 

Option C. Normal complement level: True. Unlike other conditions such as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), TTP is not typically associated with complement activation, so complement levels are generally normal.

 

Educational objective:

 

TTP doesn't grossly affect the standard coagulation tests. So, the coagulation tests such as PT (prothrombin time) and APTT (activated partial thromboplastin time) are typically normal. Direct lines from Robbins… “If coagulation tests indicate a major consumption of procoagulants, the diagnosis of TTP is doubtful”.

 

Mnemonic for TTP Clinical Features (Pentad):

 

FAT RN

 

  • Fever
  • Anemia (microangiopathic hemolytic)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal dysfunction (mild to moderate)
  • Neurologic symptoms

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 665

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a history of recurrent ear infections, easy bruising, and severe eczema. On examination, the child has widespread petechiae and a weeping rash over his arms and legs. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia with an average platelet volume less than the reference range. The boy's immunoglobulin levels are also noted to be abnormally low. The presence of small sized platelets on the peripheral smear is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

Option D:

Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is characterized by the triad of:

  • Severe eczema
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent infections

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is characterized by the triad of eczema, thrombocytopenia (with small platelets), and immunodeficiency, which corresponds to the clinical presentation of this patient.

Explanation:

Option A. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura [ITP]: ITP is characterized by autoimmune destruction of platelets, typically leading to thrombocytopenia with normal-sized platelets and no associated eczema or immunodeficiency.

Option B. Bernard-Soulier syndrome: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a platelet function disorder due to a deficiency in glycoprotein Ib, the platelet receptor for von Willebrand factor. Patients may have thrombocytopenia with large platelets and no associated eczema or immunodeficiency.

Option C. Disseminated intravascular coagulation [DIC]: DIC is a secondary condition resulting from another underlying disease. It is characterized by widespread activation of coagulation, which can lead to the consumption of platelets and coagulation factors. Platelet size is typically not affected, and it is not associated with eczema or immunodeficiency.

Educational Objective:

The characteristic features of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, include thrombocytopenia with small platelets, eczema, and recurrent infections due to immunodeficiency.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 243

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a history of chronic gastritis presents with weight loss and early satiety. An endoscopy with biopsy is performed, revealing a 2 cm lesion in the antrum of the stomach. Histopathology reports a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. Additional staining shows the cancer is confined to the gastric wall with no evidence of metastasis. In early gastric carcinoma, the malignancy is confined to which of the following layers?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucosa and submucosa

 

Option B:

 

Involvement of both the mucosa and submucosa suggests a deeper invasion than option A but still within the confines of the stomach wall, representing an intermediate stage of disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. If a gastric carcinoma is confined to the mucosa, it indicates that the tumor has not penetrated beyond the innermost layer of the stomach, which is associated with a less aggressive disease and often a more favorable prognosis.

 

Option C. Penetration into the muscularis propria denotes a more advanced local invasion compared to options A and B, suggesting a higher risk of further spread and a worse prognosis if not treated promptly.

 

Option D. Invasion of the serosa, the outermost layer of the stomach, implies that the tumor may be at the stage where it is capable of spreading beyond the stomach to adjacent structures or through the peritoneal surface, which would denote a more advanced and aggressive disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early gastric carcinoma, the malignancy confined to the mucosa and submucosa signifies a depth of invasion that is more advanced than the mucosal layer alone, but not yet extending into the muscularis propria or serosa.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 775

choices.text: Normal platelet count and normal bleeding time
Normal platelet count and increased bleeding time
Decreased platelet count and increased bleeding time
Normal platelet count and decreased bleeding time

questions.text: Patient with bleeding due to platelet function defects has which of the following features?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal platelet count and increased bleeding time  

 

Option B:

 

This option is characteristic of platelet function defects. Although there is a normal quantity of platelets (platelet count), the quality or function of these platelets is compromised, which means they don't work as they should, leading to a prolonged bleeding time

 

Platelet function defects typically result in impaired platelet aggregation or adhesion, leading to increased bleeding time. However, the platelet count remains normal in these conditions because the number of platelets is adequate, but their function is compromised. Therefore, the features of bleeding due to platelet function defects include a normal platelet count and an increased bleeding time.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Normal platelet count and normal bleeding time: This option would suggest no defect in platelet function or number, which would not typically be associated with a bleeding disorder.

 

Option C. Decreased platelet count and increased bleeding time: This suggests a quantitative defect of platelets, such as thrombocytopenia, rather than a functional defect. Although patients with thrombocytopenia will also have an increased bleeding time, the platelet count in functional defects remains normal.

 

Option D. Normal platelet count and decreased bleeding time: A decreased bleeding time indicates an efficient clotting process, which would not align with platelet function defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Platelet function defects present with a normal platelet count but impaired function, leading to an increased bleeding time, whereas quantitative disorders would show an altered platelet count.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 655

questions.text: Q34. A 60-year-old male with a known history of multiple myeloma presents with worsening renal function. A renal biopsy is performed to assess the renal involvement. Which of the following findings would be considered atypical or not commonly associated with renal complications of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Wire loop lesions

Option C:

Wire loop lesions: Wire loop lesions, seen on renal biopsy, are characteristic of lupus nephritis, a renal manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This finding is not typically associated with multiple myeloma.

Explanation:

Option A: Tubular casts: These can result from the precipitation of light chains in the renal tubules, leading to cast formation. This is a common finding in multiple myeloma-associated renal disease.

Option B: Amyloidosis: Amyloid deposition in the kidneys is a known complication of multiple myeloma, leading to renal impairment.

Option D: Renal tubular necrosis: Direct infiltration of myeloma cells into the renal tubules can cause tubular necrosis, contributing to renal dysfunction.

Educational Objective:

Wire loop lesions are not typically associated with multiple myeloma and are characteristic of lupus nephritis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 225)

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a clinical presentation of gastric outlet obstruction undergoes endoscopic biopsy of a gastric lesion. Histopathology indicates a mesenchymal tumor consistent with a GIST. Immunohistochemistry is crucial for definitive diagnosis. Which of the following markers is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis of GIST?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DOG-1

 

Option D:

 

DOG-1: Discovered on GIST-1 (DOG-1) is a highly sensitive and specific marker for GISTs, used particularly when CD117 may be negative or equivocal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CD34: While CD34 can be expressed in GISTs, it is not as specific as other markers and can be present in a variety of other soft tissue tumors.

 

Option B. CD117: Also known as c-KIT, CD117 is a commonly expressed marker in GISTs and is considered a hallmark of diagnosis. However, it is not exclusive to GISTs and may require additional confirmation.

 

Option C. CD30: This marker is not commonly associated with GISTs and is more typically related to lymphoid malignancies, such as Hodgkin lymphoma and anaplastic large cell lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DOG-1 is an important immunohistochemical marker for GISTs, especially when used alongside or in place of CD117, to confirm the diagnosis of GISTs in a biopsy sample.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/779

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common presentation of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyperviscosity

Option B:

(Hyperviscosity): Hyperviscosity syndrome is less commonly a presenting feature of multiple myeloma. It results from the high protein content in the blood due to excessive production of monoclonal proteins by myeloma cells, but not all patients will experience this.

Explanation:

Option A: (Anemia): Anemia is a common finding in multiple myeloma, typically normocytic and normochromic, caused by the replacement of bone marrow with myeloma cells, which impairs normal blood cell production.

Option C: (Bone Pains): Bone pain, particularly in the back or chest, is a very common symptom of multiple myeloma. It results from bone destruction due to the infiltration and activation of osteoclasts by myeloma cells, leading to lytic lesions or fractures.

Option D: (Infection): Patients with multiple myeloma have an increased risk of infections due to an impaired immune response, both from the disease itself and as a consequence of treatment, making infection a common presentation.

Educational Objective:

Hyperviscosity is the least common presentation of multiple myeloma compared to anemia, bone pains, and infection.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 609)

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of hemophilia A requires a blood product transfusion during a surgical procedure. ABO incompatibility is not seen with:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cryoprecipitate

Option D:

Cryoprecipitate is prepared from FFP by cold precipitation and contains a high concentration of specific coagulation factors like fibrinogen, factor VIII, factor XIII, and von Willebrand factor. It has minimal plasma and ABO antigens, reducing the risk of ABO incompatibility reactions.

Explanation:

Option A. Fresh frozen plasma: FFP contains all coagulation factors, including soluble ABO antigens. ABO incompatibility can lead to hemolytic reactions; thus, it should be matched with the recipient's blood group.

Option B. Platelet-rich plasma: PRP is derived from whole blood and retains the ABO antigens. Transfusion with incompatible PRP can also lead to hemolytic reactions.

Option C. Single donor platelets: Single donor platelets carry the donor's ABO antigens, and while the risk is lower compared to red cell transfusion, ABO compatibility is still preferred to minimize the risk of reaction.

Educational Objective:

While ABO matching is ideal for all blood components, cryoprecipitate is the least likely to cause an ABO incompatibility reaction due to its low content of plasma and ABO antigens.

 

Ref: Wintrobes 12th /850

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the clinic with recurrent, spontaneous joint hemarthroses. Family history is significant for similar symptoms in his maternal uncles. Laboratory evaluation reveals a specific factor deficiency. Which laboratory finding is most consistent with a diagnosis of Hemophilia A?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prolonged PTT

Option A:

PTT is prolonged by deficiency of factors XII, XI, IX, III, X, V, prothrombin and fibrinogen and drugs like hep­arin  

Hemophilia A is characterized by the deficiency of factor 8 and decreased activity of intrinsic pathway. This is associated with prolongation of partial thromboplastin time.

Prolonged PTT: This is the correct answer. Hemophilia A is caused by a deficiency in factor VIII, which is part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway. The activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT) test evaluates the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways and will be prolonged in Hemophilia A.

Explanation:

Option B. Prolonged PT: The prothrombin time (PT) test evaluates the extrinsic and common pathways.

Option C. Low platelet count: Hemophilia A does not affect the platelet count; it is a coagulation factor deficiency and does not involve quantitative platelet defects.

Option D. Abnormal BT: Bleeding time tests primary hemostasis, which includes platelet function.

Educational Objective:

Hemophilia A, a genetic disorder characterized by factor VIII deficiency leads to impaired function of the intrinsic coagulation pathway. This manifests clinically with a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT) and a normal prothrombin time (PT) and bleeding time (BT).

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 668

questions.text: The biopsy of the small intestine from a patient presenting with gastrointestinal symptoms shows increased cells within the intra-epithelial layer of the mucosa. In the intra-epithelial region of the mucosa of intestine the predominant cell population is that of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T-cells

 

Option B:

 

Intra-epithelial lymphocytes (IELs) are predominantly T cells, especially CD8+ T cells in the small intestine, which function in the immune response to pathogens and in maintaining epithelial integrity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. B cells are a vital part of the adaptive immune system and are present in the gut-associated lymphoid tissue; however, they are not the predominant cell type in the intra-epithelial region.

 

Option C. Plasma cells are found in the lamina propria where they produce antibodies, especially IgA, which is critical for mucosal immunity, but they are not the primary cell type in the intra-epithelial space.

 

Option D. Basophils are part of the innate immune system and are found in the blood; they are not typically located within the intra-epithelial layer of the intestinal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the intra-epithelial region of the mucosa of the intestine, the predominant cell population is that of CD8+ T-cells, which are dispersed among the luminal epithelial cells.

 

Direct quote. ‘IEL are a distinctive population of T cells dispersed among the luminal epithelial cells. Particular­ly in the small intestine, there is a predominance of CD 8+T cells.

 

 Ref: Mucosal Immunology Elsevier, 3rd/565

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with easy bruising and prolonged bleeding after minor injuries. She has a family history of bleeding disorders. Which of the following is caused by VWF factor deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) deficiency can lead to several effects on the coagulation process:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Defect platelet function: True. VWF plays a crucial role in platelet adhesion by binding to platelets and stabilizing the interaction between platelets and the damaged blood vessel wall. Its reduced levels lead to reduced platelet functioning.

 

Option B. Reduced factor VIII in plasma: True. VWF serves as a carrier protein for factor VIII, protecting it from rapid clearance and degradation. Therefore, a deficiency in VWF can result in decreased levels of factor VIII in the plasma.

 

Option C. Defective platelet adhesion: True. VWF is essential for the initial adhesion of platelets to the damaged blood vessel wall, facilitating the formation of a stable plug at the site of injury.

 

So, the correct answer is (d) All of the above. Von Willebrand factor deficiency affects both platelet function and factor VIII levels in the plasma.

 

Educational objective:

 

VWF deficiency impairs platelet adhesion and aggregation at the site of vascular injury, and reduces the plasma level of factor VIII by decreasing its stability in circulation.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 660

questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allen test is used to asses chemical mutagenicity

 

Option B:

 

Allen test: The Allen test is used to assess collateral blood flow to the hands, generally in preparation for a procedure that has the potential to disrupt blood flow in either the radial or the ulnar artery.

 

The Ames test is a widely employed method to asses chemical mutagenicity using salmonella bacteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Benzo[a]pyrene, are formed during the high-temperature combustion of tobacco in cigarettes and are implicated in the causation of lung cancer.

 

Option C. Indirect-acting carcinogens require metabolic conversion to become active carcinogens by using cytochrome P-450–dependent monooxygenases

 

Option D. The Ames test uses several strains of the bacterium Salmonella typhimurium that carry mutations in genes involved in histidine synthesis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Ames test checks the capability of the tested substance in creating mutations that result in a return to a "prototrophic" state, so that the cells can grow on a histidine-free medium.

choices.text: Immediate refrigeration to preserve factor viability

questions.text: True about prothrombin time to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Done within 2 hours

 

Option C:

 

Done within 2 hours: PT testing should be performed within a specified time from sample collection, often within 2 hours, to ensure the viability of the coagulation factors, especially the labile factors V and VIII, which can deteriorate over time at room temperature.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Immediate refrigeration to preserve factor viability: While it's true that certain coagulation factors are temperature sensitive, prothrombin time (PT) testing typically requires the sample to be kept at room temperature to prevent the cold activation of factors and potential precipitation of fibrinogen. Immediate refrigeration is not required for PT.

 

Option B. Platelet-rich plasma is essential: PT is actually performed on platelet-poor plasma, not platelet-rich plasma. The presence of platelets can affect the test results by providing phospholipid surfaces that could artificially shorten the clotting time.

 

Option D. Activated with kaolin: PT is not activated with kaolin. Instead, thromboplastin (a combination of tissue factor and phospholipids) is used to activate the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. Kaolin is used as an activator in the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) test, which evaluates the intrinsic pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The PT test must be done on platelet-poor plasma and usually within 2 hours of sample collection to ensure accurate results, using thromboplastin for activation.

 

 

Ref: Dacie and Lewis practical hematology 10th/392, 398

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a diagnosis of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) returns for a follow-up visit. She previously responded well to a course of glucocorticoids but presented again with petechiae and a platelet count of 25,000/μL. She has no splenomegaly on examination. All the following statements are correct about treatment in chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Relapse is rare

Option B:

This statement is incorrect because relapses after initial treatment with glucocorticoids are common in chronic ITP.

Explanation:

Option A. While initial treatment with glucocorticoids can be effective, many patients with chronic ITP may not achieve sustained remission and can experience relapses.

Option C. Splenectomy is typically considered after glucocorticoids and other medical therapies have failed, making it not a first-line treatment, but rather a treatment for relapsed or refractory cases.

Option D. Some patients with chronic ITP do not respond to conventional therapies or relapse following initial therapy, which may suggest a refractory form of the disease.

Educational Objective:

Direct quote…. “Almost all patients respond to gluco­corticoids (which inhibit phagocyte function), but many eventually relapse.”

  • In individuals with severe thrombocytopenia, sple­nectomy normalizes the platelet counts.
  • Immunomodulatory agents such as intravenous immunoglobulin or anti-CD20 antibody (rituximab) are often effective in patients who relapse after splenectomy or for whom splenectomy is contraindicated.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 659

questions.text: All are B cell lymphomas except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mycosis fungoides

 

Option B:

Mycosis fungoides is not a B-cell lymphoma; it is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. It primarily involves the skin and represents a neoplastic proliferation of mature T-helper cells.

Explanation:

 Option A: Burkitt's lymphoma is indeed a B-cell lymphoma. It is an aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is associated with the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and characterized by the translocation involving the MYC gene.

Option C: Mantle cell lymphoma is a B-cell lymphoma characterized by the proliferation of malignant B-cells with characteristic involvement of the mantle zone in lymphoid follicles.

Option D: Follicular lymphoma is a B-cell lymphoma. It is a slow-growing, indolent lymphoma characterized by the proliferation of abnormal B-cells within the lymph nodes.

Educational Objective:

Mycosis fungoides is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma and not a B-cell lymphoma.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 606)

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent nosebleeds, easy bruising, and prolonged bleeding after minor injuries. He has a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex. Glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex is deficient in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glanzmann disease

   Option B:

Glanzmann disease is a congenital platelet disorder characterized by a deficiency or dysfunction of the glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex on the surface of platelets. This complex is essential for platelet aggregation by binding fibrinogen and facilitating platelet-platelet interaction. In Glanzmann disease, impaired platelet aggregation leads to a tendency for prolonged bleeding.

Explanation:

Option A. Bernard Soulier syndrome is associated with a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex.

Option C. von Willebrand disease is associated with deficiencies or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, not the glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex.

Option D. Gray platelet syndrome is a rare platelet disorder characterized by grayish platelets and a deficiency of alpha-granules.

Educational objective:

 Glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex is deficient in Glanzmann’s disease.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /120
