questions.text: A 30-year-old male requires a blood transfusion after a severe car accident. He is known to have the Bombay phenotype. Prior to the transfusion, his blood sample is sent to the laboratory for compatibility testing. Based on his blood group, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lack of antigens of several blood group systems

Option C:

  • People with Bombay phenotype (rarest blood group in the world) express no A, B or H antigens on the red blood cells. These are homozygous for the silent h allele (being represented h). So, these antigens are not present in the saliva also. As the antigens are not expressed, so, the H, A and B antibody will always be present in serum.
  • ABO antigens are present not only on the red blood cells abut also on the other blood cells, in most body fluids (except CSF), cell membrane of tissues such as intestine, urothelium and vascular endothelium.

He lacks antigens from multiple blood group systems: This statement is incorrect. Individuals with the Bombay phenotype only lack antigens in the ABO blood group system specifically related to A, B, and H antigens. They do not lack antigens from other blood group systems.

Explanation:

Option A. His red blood cells lack H, A, and B antigens: This statement is correct. Individuals with the Bombay blood group do not express A, B, or H antigens on their red blood cells due to a homozygous mutation in the H gene (hh genotype).

Option B. His saliva does not contain H, A, and B substances: This statement is correct. The lack of H antigen also affects the presence of these antigens in body fluids, including saliva, because the H antigen is a precursor for A and B antigen synthesis.

Option D. His serum contains antibodies against H, A, and B antigens: This statement is correct. Because individuals with the Bombay phenotype do not express A, B, or H antigens on their red blood cells, they will form antibodies against these antigens if exposed.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Individuals with the Bombay phenotype lack A, B, and H antigens on their red blood cells and in their saliva, and their serum contains antibodies against these antigens.

 

Ref: Wintrobe’s hematology 12th/635-6

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with painless enlargement of a cervical lymph node. Excisional biopsy reveals a subtype of Hodgkin’s disease, which is histogenetically distinct from all the other subtypes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lymphocyte predominant

Option A:

Lymphocyte Predominant: This subtype is characterized by a nodular pattern with a predominance of lymphocytes and the presence of popcorn cells (Lacunar cells). Popcorn cells are large, atypical mononuclear or multinucleated cells. This subtype is generally associated with an excellent prognosis.

Explanation:

Option B: Nodular Sclerosis: Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma in the world. It is characterized by the presence of collagen bands dividing the lymph node architecture into nodules. Reed-Sternberg cells, the hallmark cells of Hodgkin's lymphoma, are found in lacunar spaces. This subtype often affects young adults and typically presents with mediastinal involvement. It has a favorable prognosis.

Option C: Mixed Cellularity: This subtype is characterized by a mixed inflammatory infiltrate, including eosinophils, plasma cells, and histiocytes, along with Reed-Sternberg cells. It is often associated with an advanced stage of the disease and has a less favorable prognosis compared to nodular sclerosis.

Option D: Lymphocyte Depleted: This subtype is characterized by a scarcity of lymphocytes and an abundance of Reed-Sternberg cells. It is associated with an advanced stage of the disease and is often seen in immunocompromised individuals. Lymphocyte-depleted Hodgkin's lymphoma has a less favorable prognosis.

Educational objective:

Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s disease is histogenetically distinct from other subtypes, characterized by a nodular pattern with a predominance of lymphocytes and the presence of popcorn cells.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 613)
